content.description:
Work up a right-trending crack to gain the slightly overhanging face. At times the holds can be difficult to find, but you'll know when you've found them.

This is a tricky route overall, but it is enjoyable and should clean up nicely.
content.protection: 6 bolts to rings.
content.location: From the lower section of Morning Glory, hug the cliffband, and go up a steep hill for about 150'. This will be the first line of bolts going up the middle of the face.

content.description: Put in work on a thin face to a small roof, you'll be rewarded with positive holds to the anchors. There is groundfall potential until you pass the roof, and this fall involves hitting a prominent stump.
content.protection: 4 bolts and maybe gear 1-2" to protect the roof.
content.location: Begin on a blank face below a small roof. Start directly in front of the infamous stump.

climbs.name: There's a Bear! Where? Right There!

content.description: Climb a thoughtful crux through a bulge to easier climbing finishing with a thin slab.
content.protection: 4 bolts and single rack of finger to hand-size cams.
content.location:
It is just right of and shares the same anchor with

Bearington Bear Goes Boltin'

.

content.description: This is super thin and techy. A hard start leads to manageable climbing. As the name suggests, don't use the features left of the bolts (even though they are very close and totally in bounds, you must remember that the FA party is always watching you....judging you...).
content.protection: 5 bolts and some ancient coldshuts for anchors.
content.location: From the lower section of Morning Glory, hug the cliffband, and go up a steep hill for about 150'. This will be the second line of bolts, going up the middle of the face.

content.description: Cool stemming leads to good holds that get smaller and less positive the higher you go. There is a techy crux around bolt 5. Staying right of the bolt line is slightly easier, but still 5.10.
content.protection: 6 bolts and shares anchors with Bear Minimum.
content.location:
On the lower section of Morning Glory, it is the obvious bolt line to the right of a large, right-facing dihedral that is the start of

Bear Down On It

!

content.description: The crux is getting off the ground. This route can easily become harder than a 10 if you don’t get the correct sequence. This is essentially a bolted highball. It’s not worth climbing unless looking to warm up for the more challenging climbs to the left.
content.protection: 3 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
It is right of

UnBearably Yellow Spider

.

content.description: Techy face climbing suddenly switches up to a tricky roof move.
content.protection: 6 bolts to bolted anchors.
content.location:
Just left of the

Disco Boy

crack, begin beneath an overhung, right-trending dihedral.

climbs.name: Rico Suave Made Me Do It

content.description: Jam and layback your way up the low angle dihedral. This has fun, varied moves with good placements throughout. Until this route gets more traffic, bring your gardening gloves.
content.protection:
Gear to 3". This shares anchors with

Church of Climbintology

.
content.location:
It ascends the slightly dirty dihedral to the immediate right of the

Church of Climbintology

roof.

content.description: This is the furthest crack on the upper wall.
content.protection:
First placement is questionable, use second bolt of

Fill 'em and Drill 'em!

Small/medium cams.
content.location:
Rap down from the anchors of

Drill 'Em and Fill 'Em

!

content.description: This is a mixed climb with fun movement down low leading to some thinner slab to the anchors.
content.protection: 4 bolts and a few cams from 0.2 to 0.75.

climbs.name: Nothin' Butt a Rainy Day Thang

content.description: This is a fantastic climb for the grade that delivers everything from undercling, slab, and layback crack moves.
content.protection: 6 bolts.

content.description: Nemesis is thin, tough, and sure to test your slab puzzle solving abilities. The crux is getting off the ground, but it doesn't let up for a few bolts.
content.protection:
6 bolts and shared anchors with

Gone Fishing

.
content.location: It is on the left end of the upper wall, right of a distinct low roof. Begin at a thin seam.

content.description: A tricky thin start leads to a good rest. From the top of the blunt arete, make a fun transition onto the face, and head up to the anchors.
content.protection: 4 bolts and maybe some finger cams for confidence.
content.location: Begin on the face just right of the distinct corner by the tree bench. Begin on a blunt arete.

content.description:
Follow the crack right next to

Amazing Feets of Glory

. The crux is getting off the ground, but this should be manageable despite being unprotected. You could bring a cam for down low, but if you’re at Morning Glory, you should be fairly comfortable leading this grade. After that, it’s super easy to the top with huge jugs and nicely placed bolts.
content.protection: 5ish bolts and maybe a cam.
content.location:
It is right of

Amazing Feets of Glory

content.description: Follow the obvious crack on the slab where there is a splitter about 15 feet up. The splitter is the crux most definitely. Laybacks and friction on your feet are a must to get solid progression through. After the splitter, there are solid hands and feet the rest of the way the slab. There is a two bolt anchor up top just below a tree.
content.protection: Take a small rack up to #2. There is a great little crack up top where you can place a #12 nut, just before you top out.
content.location:
The route is on the upper area of Morning Glory. Once you arrive at the lower area of Morning Glory, you will see an obvious trail leading up to the middle and upper areas. Once you get to the upper area you'll see a lonely rock on the east side of the little trail just at the base of the crag. If you stand in front of the rock and look at the wall, you will see a tree growing right up next to the slab. To the left of the tree, you will see the bulge, which makes up part of the splitter on the route. Another dead giveaway is that everything is bolted with the exception of two routes...this one and

Old Trad Crack

(5.9).

climbs.name: Fingerbanger
climbs.fa: M. Weinberger, A. Morano, S. Burke

content.description: Follow easy steps up to a large ledge to begin the real fun. Use the crack between the two perpendicular walls to ascend using good footwork. The crux is getting off the large ledge. Laybacks and stems will bring you to the two bolt anchor. An attentive belayer is a must, as the ledgy nature of the lower half could allow for some nasty falls.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Follow the fallen over tree to the far right. From here, follow the bolts up.

content.description: This is a fun route, but it is short.  The crux is getting past 2nd bolt.
content.protection: Quickdraws.
content.location:
It is on the right side of

Old Trad Crack

.

content.description: Start up a crack system, climbing into a small, right-facing corner with a bolt out right on the face just under a roof. A second bolt protects the roof move. Move up and left past a 3rd bolt to the anchors.
content.protection:
2 bolts and a light standard rack to a #2. Shares anchors with

Amazing Feets of Glory.
content.location: This is on Upper Morning Glory Wall.

climbs.name: Dingo, Dango, Dyno
climbs.fa: Alex Morano, Sam Burke, and Chris Rohlf

content.description: This is a nice line that finishes with the crux. Bolts one and two move through the lower easy section. Bolts three and four involve slab movement but are still fairly easy. After clipping bolt five, follow the block hanging out of the wall to clip bolt six. From here, it is a committing move to a jug. Clip the anchors from the jug.
content.protection: 6 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: It is the farthest right route.

content.description: A tricky roof move leads to thin face climbing. This looks very dire from the ground, but it gets less dire once you're on it.
content.protection: 6 bolts to anchors.
content.location: On the upper section of Morning Glory, begin beneath a distinct low roof.

climbs.name: Chris Wilson Made Me Do It
climbs.fa: whoever Chris Wilson forced to climb

content.description: Work up the path of least resistance in a broken crack system just right of the mini-buttress. The rock quality is sandy and exfoliating at times, and there are still some loose rocks, so wear a helmet.
content.protection: Gear to 3".
content.location: From the lower section of Morning Glory, hug the cliffband, and go up a steep hill for about 150'. This will be just right of the first line of bolts you see.

content.description: Easy moves to a high first bolt leads to a juggy face. Things thin out up top.
content.protection: 5 bolts and shared anchors with the 5.11 on the right.
content.location: On the lower section of Morning Glory, this is the second rightmost route. The start is directly in front of a live tree growing at the base of the wall.

content.description:
Bear Minimum is aptly named. Protection is scarce and not ideal, but one is able to clip bolts from neighboring routes if need be. Climbing it on TR is a far more enjoyable experience and is strongly recommended.

You can set up a toprope by going left after climbing

Bearington Bear Goes Boltin'.
content.protection: 1 bolt, gear to 0.75", and bolted anchors.
content.location:
It is the second line right of the right-facing dihedral that marks the start of

Bear Down on It!

content.description: Follow a crack to a nice ledge, then climb past 3 bolts of face climbing to a 2 bolt anchor - high quality moves. The protection is great before the bolted finish.
content.protection: 3 bolts and a light standard rack to a #2 C4.

content.description: This is a short but super fun line! As the name implies, layback the crack (pumpy!) until you can make an interesting transition to the face. It protects well and is worth the walk.
content.protection: Gear to 3". A #4 was nice for the lower section. It has bolted anchors.
content.location: On the lower section of Morning Glory on the far left side of the wall, this is the obvious, tapering crack left of a small roof.

content.description:
I am adding this for historical sake. I did not climb this - it looked wicked dirty, and we ran out of daylight. This seemed kind of fun from afar.

While the route has recently been extensively cleaned by the FA party, loose rocks persist and it would be wise to wear a helmet.
content.protection:
Gear, and it shares coldshut anchors with

TotLL

.
content.location: From the lower section of Morning Glory, hug the cliffband, and go up a steep hill for about 150'. This is the broken crack system to the left of 2 bolted lines.

content.description:
A tricky start yields to easier but sustained slabbin' goodness. There is a second crux higher up.

About 2/3rds of the way up, the bolts stop, and it is runnout as the dickens! Thankfully it is very easy, and if you made it this far, you're unlikely to fall, but still....just take the path of least resistance, and aim for the anchors directly above the small pine.
content.protection: 6 bolts.
content.location: The furthest right bolted line on the upper wall, this begins right of a small roof and directly beneath a small pine.
